description.narrative: In this sense, this project is intended to close some of the main gaps in the information generation cycle (from the community climate observers all the way to the dissemination of the forecasts and alerts, through the analysis and processing of meteorological data that is relevant to producers). It is also contributing directly to the adaptation of farmers to climate change by developing a model for climate resilient families (CRFM), consisting of best practices identified and validated by the producers themselves. The project aims to develop the model, to allow measurement of resilience of a family in an integral way. The innovative element of putting the family at the centre of adaptation to climate change is that it enables to enter the private sphere and also tackle important issues related to gender equality and women’s empowerment as key figures in income generation, protection of family livelihood and community-based leadership and decision-making.

This project, building on existing efforts by the three implementing partners, aims to: a)Strengthen the capacities of community-based climate observers, especially women, so that they gather and share the information with technical experts, The exchange between observers and experts will allow for development of capacities of analysis and inquiry about the information that is being generated regarding the climate. Traditional knowledge combined with scientific information will allow us to better understand how climate change is influencing the territories, and to find if there is a pattern that allows to build a new cycle in rainfall patterns. b)Improve the quality and dissemination of the information (bulletins and warnings) by Soppexcca’s data management team. See examples of bulletins from a previous project here. c)Ensure a broader reach by training local media in climate information dissemination; a)Assist families in the adoption of best agricultural practices based on accurate climate information.
